resources.string:
Resistor values are an easy enough calculation once you get to remembering the colours. Resistors are almost always labeled with 4-6 coloured bands; the bands will have a large 'gap' in the middle with 3-4 bands on one side and 1-2 bands on the other(three on 1 side and 1 on the other for a 4 band resistor. This gap shows us what the different bands represent. 

 	Assuming you're holding the resistor with the side that has more bands before the gap to your left; all the bands except for the one right before the gap, 1-2 or 1-3 depending on the number of bands, are the Digit Bands. These bands represent the actual number values. The final band on the left side before the gap is the multiplier band, this represents a power of 10 that you multiply the digit bands by to get the total number of ohms. The first band after the gap, (there may be only one after gap), is the Tolerance band. This band represents the level of error plus or minus a percent in the value of the resistor. If there is a 6th and final band, this band is the Tempurature band and shows the level of variance in resistance per degree celsius. 

 	For example say we have a 4 band resistor like this one:

\tThe first two bands are the Digit bands, the third band would be the multiplier band, and that forth band after the gap, (its hard to see in a picture but in real life the gap size difference is there), is the tolerance band. \n\n \tSo the first two bands are Yellow(4) and Purple(7), this means our base number is 47. Looking at the third band we see that it is Black(0) which means we multiply our 47 by 10 to the power of 0, which is 1, so our final ohms value is 47. Finally we tack on our tolerance band Gold(5%) meaning that our resistor is a 47ohm resistor with plus or minus 5% tolerance!
